Greetings.explanation: The quintessential Australian greeting, short for 'Good day'
examples: G'day John, how ya going?
She just walked in and said g'day to everyone.
notes: Despite what foreigners think, most Australians don't actually add 'mate' after every g'day.

Greetings.explanation: The Australian way of asking 'How are you?' or 'How's it going?'
examples: How ya going today?
How ya going with that project?
notes: This is probably the most common greeting you'll hear in Australia.

Greetings.explanation: Asking what's happening or what's the plan
examples: What's the go tonight?
Hey mate, what's the go with that project?
So what's the go, are we heading out or staying in?
notes: Often used when arriving at a gathering or meeting up with friends.

Greetings.explanation: Asking what's new or what's been happening with someone
examples: Hey Sarah, what's news?
Long time no see! What's news with you?
What's news in your world?
notes: A common way to start a conversation, especially when you haven't seen someone for a while.

Greetings.explanation: A uniquely Australian way of asking how someone is doing
examples: How're you travelling these days?
G'day Tom, how're you travelling with that new job?
How're you travelling after your surgery?
notes: Doesn't literally refer to travel - it's asking about your general state or progress.

Greetings.explanation: Asking what's happening, what's going on
examples: What's cracking this weekend?
Hey mate, what's cracking?
So what's cracking at the party tonight?
notes: More common among younger Australians.

Greetings.explanation: Asking how someone has been since you last saw them
examples: Hey Johnno, how ya been?
How ya been? Haven't seen you in donkey's years!
How ya been keeping yourself?
notes: Can be stretched out to sound like 'How ya beeeeen?' for emphasis.

Greetings.explanation: A casual, attention-grabbing greeting popular in Australia
examples: Oi! Come over here and say hello!
Oi, Smithy! Long time no see.
Oi oi oi! Look who it is!
notes: Can sound rude to non-Australians, but it's often just a friendly way to get someone's attention.

General.explanation: Australia's way of saying 'you're welcome' or 'it's not a problem'
examples: Thanks for helping me move house. - No worries mate!
Sorry I'm late. - No worries, we just got here ourselves.
Can I get this tomorrow instead? - No worries!
notes: Probably the most common Australian phrase, used in almost any situation.

examples: Let's meet up this arvo for coffee
I've got nothing planned for the arvo
See you this arvo!

General.explanation: Australian way of saying 'a lot' or 'very'
examples: That film was heaps good!
There's heaps of time before the train comes
Thanks heaps for your help!

General.explanation: Something that is genuine, real, or true
examples: Is that fair dinkum? You're not having me on?
He's fair dinkum, you can trust what he says
Fair dinkum, I didn't know that!
notes: One of Australia's oldest slang terms, dating back to the gold rush days.

General.explanation: An emphatic way of saying 'yes, absolutely' or 'that's definitely true'
examples: Are you coming to the barbie on Saturday? - Bloody oath I am!
That game last night was amazing. - Bloody oath it was!
I reckon we should leave early to beat the traffic
What do you reckon about the new boss?
She reckons she'll get the job

General.explanation: A contradictory phrase meaning 'no' but acknowledging the question
examples: Do you want another beer? - Yeah, nah, I'm good thanks
Should we go to that new restaurant? - Yeah, nah, I'm not in the mood
notes: The reverse 'Nah, yeah' means 'yes'.

General.explanation: Everything will be okay or work out fine
examples: Don't stress about the presentation, she'll be right
The car's making a weird noise. - She'll be right, mate

General.explanation: A casual way of saying goodbye
examples: I've gotta head off now, catch ya later!
Catchya tomorrow at the barbie.
Catch ya later, don't do anything I wouldn't do!
notes: Sometimes shortened to just 'Catchya'.

General.explanation: In Australia, a 'doona' is a quilt or duvet used on a bed.
examples: It's getting cold at night, I might put another doona on the bed
Can you wash the doona cover before the guests arrive?
notes: This term is uniquely Australian and comes from the brand name that became generic, similar to how 'Band-Aid' is used for adhesive bandages.

General.explanation: In Australia, 'servo' means a petrol station or gas station.
examples: Stop at the servo and grab a meat pie.
We filled up the tank at the servo outside town.
Don't forget your sunnies, it's blazing out.
I lost my sunnies at the beach again!
I haven't seen you in yonks!
It's been yonks since I've been to Melbourne
That happened yonks ago
notes: Used to exaggerate how long something has been

examples: I'll save that for ron
We can deal with that ron
Maybe ron we'll go to the beach
notes: Rhyming slang - 'later ron' becomes just 'ron'

General.explanation: A short amount of time, from 5 minutes up to an hour
examples: Give us a tick, I'll be right back
Wait a tick while I grab my keys
It'll only take a tick

General.explanation: Very busy, having no free time
examples: I've been flat chat at work all week
Sorry I can't help, I'm flat chat today
She's been flat chat with the kids

General.explanation: An exclamation of surprise or amazement
examples: Streuth! Look at the size of that spider!
Streuth, that was close!
Streuth mate, you scared me!
notes: Short for 'God's truth' - shows surprise or disbelief

examples: Ta mate, appreciate it
Ta for helping me move
Ta very much!
notes: Very informal, used with in light conversation, not in serious or professional situations

General.explanation: Maybe, but probably not - a polite way of saying no
examples: Can we go to the beach tomorrow? - We'll see
Will you buy me that toy? - We'll see
We'll see how the weather goes
notes: Often means 'probably not' when said by parents

General.explanation: Great, excellent, or agreeing to something
examples: That car is sweet!
Sweet, see you at 7pm then
Everything's sweet mate
notes: Can mean both 'good' and 'okay/agreed'

examples: Welcome to Straya mate!
Straya Day is January 26th
That's so Straya
notes: Often used with pride or humor about Australian culture

General.explanation: A small corner shop selling basic groceries, drinks and snacks
examples: I'll grab some bread from the milk bar
The milk bar on the corner has everything
Can you get some ice cream from the milk bar?
notes: Like a convenience store but more community-focused

General.explanation: The city, especially when coming from a rural area
examples: I'm heading to the big smoke for work
Life in the big smoke is different
She moved from the farm to the big smoke
notes: Usually refers to the nearest major city

examples: He lives out in the sticks
Mobile coverage is terrible in the sticks
I grew up in the sticks, nothing but trees
notes: Refers to areas with lots of trees, far from cities

General.explanation: A utility vehicle - pickup truck with an open back
examples: Chuck it in the back of the ute
My ute's perfect for moving furniture
Every tradie needs a good ute
notes: Short for 'utility vehicle' - essential Australian vehicle

General.explanation: A short work break, originally for smoking but now any break
examples: Time for smoko, everyone down tools
I'll tell you at smoko
He's gone to smoko for 20 minutes
notes: Originally meant cigarette break but now means any work break

examples: Don't give me any agro mate
He's been agro all day
The bouncer got agro with the drunk guy
notes: Can be used as adjective (aggressive) or noun (aggravation)

examples: Turn on the air-con, it's bloody hot
The air-con's broken in my car
We need air-con in this office
Call an ambo, he's hurt bad
The ambo arrived in five minutes
My mate works as an ambo
notes: Short for ambulance

General.explanation: Someone showing daring, audacity, or experiencing extremely good luck
examples: That was an arsey move overtaking on that corner
He's so arsey, always gets away with everything
What an arsey shot to win the game!
notes: Derived from 'tin arsed' - can mean daring or very lucky

examples: Bags the front seat!
Can someone do the dishes? - Bags not!
I bags the last piece of cake
notes: Used to claim ownership of something, often by children

General.explanation: To corner somebody physically or trap them in conversation
examples: The angry customer bailed up the manager
He bailed me up at the pub for an hour
Don't let him bail you up with his stories
Have a bickie with your tea
The kids ate all the bickies
Tim Tams are my favorite bickies
notes: Can also mean lots of money when used as 'big bickies'

General.explanation: To brag or boast about oneself
examples: Stop big-noting yourself about the promotion
He's always big-noting himself
Don't big-note yourself, it was just luck

General.explanation: Business, often used as 'mind your own business'
examples: Mind your own bizzo mate
That's none of your bizzo
What's your bizzo here?
notes: Short for business

General.explanation: A rest, especially after physical work
examples: Let's have a blow before we continue
I need a blow after all that digging
Take a blow, you've earned it

General.explanation: Board shorts - medium-long bathing shorts originally for surfing
examples: Grab your boardies, we're going to the beach
These boardies are perfect for surfing
I live in boardies during summer
notes: From 'board shorts' - essential Australian beachwear

examples: That's a bodgy repair job
His car is pretty bodgy
Don't buy that, it looks bodgy
notes: Similar to 'dodgy' but specifically about poor quality
Can also be spelled 'bodgie'.

examples: Dinner's ready, bog in everyone!
Don't wait for me, bog in
The kids really bogged in to that cake
notes: This is similar to saying 'tuck in'.

General.explanation: Don't worry, everything's fine - a reassuring response
examples: You're right mate, no need to apologize
You're right, she'll be fine
Don't worry about it, you're right
notes: An abbreviation of 'you're alright', used to tell someone not to stress about something.

General.explanation: A casual goodbye meaning 'be careful' or 'relax'
examples: Alright mate, take it easy
See you later, take it easy on the road
Take it easy this weekend

General.explanation: A versatile goodbye wishing someone well for the day/night/weekend
examples: Catch you later, have a good one!
I'm heading off now, have a good one
Have a good one at the footy tonight
It's just a bog standard car
The phone is bog standard, nothing fancy
I want bog standard service, no extras
My car's a complete bomb
That bomb won't make it up the hill
He's driving around in an old bomb
That goal was a bottler!
What a bottler of a party
She's an absolute bottler
There are brumbies running free in the mountains
The brumbie herd moved through the valley
Brumbies are beautiful but hard to catch
notes: Australia's wild horses, descendants of escaped domestic horses

General.explanation: Stag party or bachelor party - male gathering before a wedding
examples: We're planning his buck's night
The buck's night got pretty wild
Are you coming to Dave's buck's night?
notes: Australian equivalent of bachelor party
Also called a 'bucks party

General.explanation: Little or no chance of success
examples: You've got Buckley's chance of passing that exam
Buckley's chance it'll rain today
He's got two chances - Buckley's and none
notes: From escaped convict William Buckley who survived against all odds

examples: He's wearing budgie smugglers to the beach
Those budgie smugglers are way too tight
Aussie men love their budgie smugglers
notes: Humorous name for speedos - suggests they're so tight they could smuggle budgies

examples: I'm absolutely buggered after that hike
The car's buggered, won't start
If they catch me, I'm buggered
notes: Multiple meanings depending on context

General.explanation: To put or place something; also means broken
examples: Bung it in the oven
My phone's bung, screen won't work
Just bung your bag over there
notes: Can mean 'put' or 'broken' depending on context

examples: Let's sit around the bush telly tonight
The bush telly's crackling nicely
Nothing beats watching the bush telly under the stars
notes: Humorous term - campfires provide entertainment like TV

General.explanation: Blowing your nose by blocking one nostril and blowing
examples: He did a bushman's hanky by the tree
No tissues? Time for a bushman's hanky
That's gross, use a tissue not a bushman's hanky
notes: Crude but practical method used in the bush

examples: The busker played guitar on the corner
I gave the busker five bucks
She's a great busker, always draws a crowd
How do you want your cackleberries cooked?
The chook laid some fresh cackleberries
Scrambled cackleberries for breakfast
notes: Humorous term - from the cackling sound chickens make

examples: My phone is cactus
The engine's cactus, won't start
After that crash, the car was cactus
notes: Means completely broken or dead

examples: The old dog carked it last night
My computer carked it during the storm
He nearly carked it in that accident

General.explanation: Come on! - used to encourage or cheer
examples: Carn the Bulldogs!
Carn mate, have another beer
Carn, you can do better than that
notes: Contraction of 'come on', especially used in sports

examples: That new car is the cat's pyjamas
She thinks she's the cat's pyjamas
This restaurant is the cat's pyjamas
notes: Similar to 'cat's whiskers' or 'bee's knees'

examples: The chooks are laying well this week
Grab some eggs from the chook pen
We had roast chook for dinner
notes: Very common Australian term for chicken

examples: What are you doing for Chrissie?
Chrissie dinner at my place this year
The kids are excited about Chrissie

General.explanation: Take a day off work pretending to be sick
examples: I'm chucking a sickie tomorrow
He chucked a sickie to go surfing
Don't chuck a sickie on a Monday, too obvious
notes: When you're perfectly healthy but call in sick

examples: I had a chunder after drinking too much
He chundered all over the bathroom
The boat ride made me want to chunder
notes: Classic Australian slang for vomiting

General.explanation: Fake, substitute, not the real thing
examples: That's a Clayton's apology - not really sorry
It's a Clayton's promotion - same job, fancy title
This is Clayton's democracy
notes: From Clayton's non-alcoholic drink ad: 'the drink you have when you're not having a drink'

examples: She's getting clucky seeing all those babies
Don't get clucky on me
My wife's been clucky lately
notes: From clucking hens sitting on eggs

examples: Fancy a cold one after work?
Let's grab some cold ones for the barbie
Nothing beats a cold one on a hot day

General.explanation: Make a bad mistake or have an accident
examples: He came a gutser on his bike
The company came a gutser with that investment
Watch out or you'll come a gutser
He's on compo after hurting his back
The compo claim was approved
She's been on compo for months
notes: Short for compensation

General.explanation: A call made in the bush; within earshot
examples: He's not within cooee of winning
Give us a cooee when you're ready
The house is within cooee of the beach
notes: From Aboriginal call - means within hearing distance

General.explanation: Heavily under the influence of alcohol or drugs
examples: That guy is absolutely cooked
I was so cooked last night
Don't drive, you're cooked
notes: Modern slang meaning very intoxicated

examples: He copped it sweet when the boss yelled at him
Just cop it sweet and move on
She copped it sweet and didn't argue
Don't forget your cossie for the beach
That's a nice cossie you're wearing
The kids need new cossies for summer
notes: Short for costume, also spelled 'cozzie'

examples: Mum's cranky because we're late
Don't be so cranky about it
The baby's cranky, needs a nap
Crikey! Look at the size of that spider!
Crikey, that was close!
Crikey mate, you scared me
notes: Made famous by Steve Irwin

examples: I'm feeling a bit crook today
Don't go crook at me
That's a bit crook, mate
notes: Multiple meanings - sick, angry, or unfair depending on context

examples: He's really cut about missing the game
Don't get cut, it's not worth it
She was cut when they didn't invite her
Pull your dacks up
I ripped my dacks on the fence
Nice dacks, where'd you get them?
notes: Also spelled 'daks' - general term for lower body clothing

General.explanation: An unfashionable or uncool person, but often used affectionately
examples: You're such a dag!
Dad's wearing his dag shirt again
She's a bit of a dag but we love her
notes: Can be endearing - originally meant excrement on sheep's wool

examples: Those shoes are so daggy
My dad's daggy dancing embarrasses me
That's a daggy outfit
You're dead set right about that
Dead set, that was the funniest thing I've seen
Are you dead set about moving to Perth?
That concert was deadly
Your new car is deadly bro
The surf was deadly today
notes: Adopted from Aboriginal English meaning excellent

examples: I'm so devo about missing the game
She was devo when her phone broke
Don't be devo, there's always next time
notes: Short for devastated

General.explanation: That's obvious, duh - an exasperated acknowledgment
examples: Of course it's raining - der!
You need to study for the test? Der!
Der, everyone knows that
notes: Common among children and teenagers

examples: Let's have a dekko at your new car
Take a dekko at this photo
Give us a dekko under the hood

General.explanation: To give somebody a lift on a bicycle
examples: Can you give me a dink to school?
He gave his little sister a dink on his bike
I got a dink on the handlebars
notes: Also 'double-dink' for two passengers

examples: That's fair dinkum mate
Are you dinkum about that story?
Fair dinkum, I didn't see you there
notes: Often used as 'fair dinkum' meaning honest/true

examples: He's a dinky-di Aussie
That's dinky-di Australian beef
She's dinky-di, born and bred in the bush
notes: Emphasizes authenticity, especially Australian authenticity

examples: It's going to get dirty later this afternoon
He was dirty on me after I took his parking spot
The weather turned dirty quickly
notes: Context-dependent - weather or emotions

examples: Don't dob on your brother
She dobbed me in to the teacher
He's such a dobber
notes: 'Dob in' means to report someone, 'dobber' is someone who tells tales

examples: Keep the docket for the warranty
I lost the docket for the groceries
The docket shows you paid $50
Did you watch that doco about sharks?
There's a good doco on tonight
I love nature docos
notes: Short for documentary

examples: Pull the doona up, it's cold
I need a new doona for winter
The doona fell off the bed
notes: From the brand name Doona - equivalent to British 'duvet'

examples: Don't be such a drongo
That drongo forgot his keys again
Only a drongo would try that
notes: From a type of bird known for being easily caught

examples: I'll give you the drum on what happened
Got the drum on the best place to eat?
He gave me the drum about the job
notes: Becoming less common - means inside information

examples: Put the good china in the duchess
The duchess is full of old dishes
Mum keeps the tablecloth in the duchess
notes: Furniture term - where you display dishes

General.explanation: A pacifier for babies, or an idiot
examples: The baby spat out his dummy
Don't be such a dummy
She threw a dummy spit when she didn't get her way
notes: Multiple meanings - baby's pacifier or calling someone stupid

examples: I need to use the dunny
The dunny paper's run out
That old house still has a dunny out the back
notes: Originally outdoor toilets, now any toilet

examples: She was dux of her year
He's trying to dux the physics class
The dux gets a special prize
notes: From Latin 'dux' meaning leader

General.explanation: A large sum of money, expensive
examples: That car cost big bickies
He's earning big bickies at his new job
The house renovation is going to be big bickies
notes: From 'biscuits' - means lots of money

examples: That restaurant is too exy for me
Sydney rent is so exy
The drinks at that bar are exy
notes: Short for expensive

General.explanation: Used in the phrase 'hasn't got a brass razoo' meaning very poor
examples: He hasn't got a brass razoo
I can't come out, I haven't got a brass razoo
After the divorce, she hasn't got a brass razoo
notes: A razoo was a made-up coin - means no money at all

General.explanation: A five dollar note (from its pink color)
examples: Can you lend me a prawn?
I found a prawn in my old jeans
This coffee costs more than a prawn
notes: Also called 'pink lady' or 'piglet'

General.explanation: A ten dollar note (from its blue color)
examples: That'll cost you a bluey
I've only got a bluey left
Can you change a bluey?
notes: Also called 'blue swimmer' or 'Banjo'

General.explanation: A twenty dollar note (from its red color)
examples: The taxi fare was a lobster
I need a lobster to pay for lunch
That shirt costs three lobsters
notes: From the red/orange color of the $20 note

General.explanation: A fifty dollar note (from its yellow color)
examples: Dinner cost me a pineapple
I withdrew a pineapple from the ATM
That's worth at least a pineapple
notes: From the yellow/gold color of the $50 note

General.explanation: A one hundred dollar note (from its green color)
examples: The fine was two Kermits
I've never seen a Kermit before
That's going to cost a few Kermits
notes: Also called 'watermelon', 'Granny Smith', or 'treefrog'

examples: Mum gave me an earbashing about my room
I got an earbashing from the boss
Stop giving me an earbashing
notes: Means getting told off or lectured at length

examples: Give him a fair go mate
Fair go, I was only joking
Everyone deserves a fair go
notes: Fundamental Australian value of giving everyone a chance

General.explanation: Wild, out of control, or disgusting
examples: That party was absolutely feral
He's gone feral since moving out
The bathroom was feral after the party
notes: Can describe behavior, hygiene, or situations

General.explanation: Moving as fast as possible, very busy
examples: I've been flat chat all day
The car was going flat chat down the highway
We're flat chat trying to finish this project
notes: Also 'flat out' - means maximum speed or effort

General.explanation: To get rid of something or someone
examples: Give that old car the flick
She gave him the flick after the party
I'm giving this job the flick
notes: 'Give something the flick' means to discard or dump it

General.explanation: To sell, steal, or treat roughly
examples: He flogged his car for five grand
Someone flogged my bike
Don't flog the engine like that
notes: Multiple meanings - sell, steal, or abuse something

examples: I'll fossick through the garage for tools
He's fossicking for gold in the creek
Stop fossicking through my stuff
notes: Originally meant prospecting for gold

examples: Don't forget to pack some frangers
The franger broke
Always use a franger
notes: Common slang for condom

examples: That's just a furphy
Don't believe that furphy about the boss
Sounds like another furphy to me
notes: From Furphy water carts in WWI where rumors spread

General.explanation: To take a look at something
examples: Let's go take a gander next door
Have a gander at this photo
Take a gander under the bonnet
notes: Also 'ganda' - means to look or inspect

General.explanation: To become fed up with something
examples: I got jack of working at the supermarket
She's getting jack of his excuses
Eventually I got jack of the noise
notes: Means to become tired or annoyed with something

examples: Give it a burl, you might like it
I'll give surfing a burl
Come on, give it a burl
notes: Encouragement to try something new

examples: I was gobsmacked by the news
He looked absolutely gobsmacked
That left me gobsmacked
notes: 'Gob' means mouth - so shocked your mouth hangs open

General.explanation: A party or event that's really fun and lively
examples: The place was really going off
This party's going off!
The club was going off last night
notes: Means very exciting or happening

examples: Give me the good oil on what happened
Here's the good oil about the job
I got the good oil from someone reliable
notes: Reliable inside information

examples: Good on ya for helping out
You passed the test? Good on ya!
Good on ya mate
notes: Expression of approval or congratulation

examples: That's a grouse idea
We had a grouse time at the party
What a grouse day for the beach
notes: Especially common in Victoria

General.explanation: Someone of excellent ability, above average
examples: He's a gun player
She's a gun at maths
That mechanic's a real gun
notes: From shearing - the fastest shearer was the 'gun shearer'

General.explanation: To mock, criticize, or pay out on someone
examples: Don't hang shit on him
They're just hanging shit
Stop hanging shit on my car
notes: Means to give someone a hard time

examples: Thanks heaps for helping
There's heaps of food left
I like her heaps
notes: Can mean 'lots' or be used as an intensifier like 'very'

examples: Hooly dooley, look at that!
Hooly dooley, that was close!
Hooly dooley, what a mess!
notes: Similar to 'good heavens' or 'my goodness'

General.explanation: To drive fast and recklessly, or someone who does so
examples: Stop hooning around the car park
That hoon nearly hit us
The police caught him hooning
notes: Dangerous driving, especially showing off

General.explanation: Used to say goodbye, particularly by older people in rural areas
examples: Hooroo, see you later
Hooroo mate, drive safe
Hooroo everyone!
notes: Old-fashioned but still used way of saying farewell

examples: I need a hottie for my sore back
Fill up the hottie, it's cold
The hottie leaked all over the bed
notes: Not an attractive person - that's a different meaning

General.explanation: A small Aboriginal shelter or any temporary outdoor shelter
examples: They built a humpy by the river
The old humpy's falling down
We slept in a humpy under the stars
notes: Traditional Aboriginal temporary shelter

examples: Turn off the idiot box and come outside
He's glued to the idiot box all day
Nothing good on the idiot box tonight
notes: Derogatory term for TV

General.explanation: To go somewhere in a hurry
examples: I have to jet to work
Let's jet before it gets crowded
He jetted off to the shops
notes: Means to leave quickly

General.buttonTitle: Kangaroos loose in the top paddock
examples: He's got kangaroos loose in the top paddock
That idea suggests kangaroos loose in the top paddock
She's got a few kangaroos loose
notes: Humorous way to say someone's not quite right mentally

examples: Ken oath I'll be there
Ken oath that's right
Ken oath, what a game!
notes: Polite version of a stronger expression

examples: Fill up the heater with kero
The kero lamp's running low
We need more kero for camping
notes: Short for kerosene

examples: The kids start kindie next year
She works at the local kindie
Kindie pickup is at 3pm
notes: Short for kindergarten

examples: I'm absolutely knackered
The car's knackered, won't start
After that hike I was knackered
notes: Can mean tired or broken

examples: Don't knock it until you try it
He's always knocking my cooking
Stop knocking the government
notes: Means to criticize or find fault

General.explanation: A refusal, or to refuse something
examples: I got a knock back from the bank
She knocked back his invitation
That's a real knock back
notes: To reject or be rejected

General.explanation: To take advantage of someone's gullibility
examples: He's having a lend of you
Don't have a lend of me
She's having a lend of the new guy
notes: To trick or fool someone

examples: The light globe's blown
Change the light globe in the kitchen
We need a new light globe
notes: Australian term for light bulb

examples: I don't understand the local lingo
He speaks the surfing lingo
What's all this computer lingo?
notes: Informal language or jargon

examples: I need to put on some lippy
Your lippy's smudged
What color lippy is that?
notes: Short for lipstick

General.explanation: To drop in to see someone
examples: I'll lob over later
He lobbed in unexpectedly
Lob around anytime
notes: Casual visit without prior arrangement

examples: It's London to a brick he'll be late
London to a brick it'll rain
London to a brick she'll win
notes: Betting odds expression meaning very certain

General.explanation: The side of the road where livestock graze during droughts
examples: The cattle are on the long paddock
Drought's so bad they're using the long paddock
Stock on the long paddock again
notes: Roadside grazing during tough times

examples: He's got some lurk going
That sounds like a lurk to me
What's your lurk?
notes: A scam or dodgy scheme

examples: The manchester sale is on
We need new manchester for the guest room

Regional.explanation: Northern Territory's two distinct seasons
examples: The Wet is coming
I prefer the Dry season

Regional.explanation: Alice Springs
examples: He's from Alice
Alice is in the middle of nowhere

Regional.explanation: Central Australia around Uluru/Alice Springs
examples: The Red Centre is stunning
We're touring the Red Centre

Regional.explanation: Rural/remote areas of Australia
examples: He grew up in the bush
City folk don't understand the bush

Regional.explanation: Middle of nowhere, very remote location
examples: They live in Woop Woop
That's out in Woop Woop somewhere

Regional.explanation: Very remote location, beyond the town of Bourke in NSW
examples: He's from back o' Bourke
That's back o' Bourke country

Regional.explanation: Large cattle or sheep property in rural Australia
examples: He works on a cattle station
The station covers thousands of acres

Regional.explanation: Young man working on a cattle station to learn farming
examples: He's working as a jackaroo
The jackaroo life is tough

Regional.explanation: Young woman working on a cattle station to learn farming
examples: She's a jillaroo on a Northern Territory station
Jillaroo work is hard but rewarding

People.explanation: A person who is unsophisticated or from a lower socio-economic background. Often loud, uncultured, and wears tacky clothes.
examples: Look at that bloke in the flannel and thongs  total bogan.
This pub is full of bogans tonight.
notes: The term 'bogan' is often used insultingly, but some Australians embrace it proudly.

People.explanation: A universal term for friend or acquaintance in Australia
examples: Hey mate, how's it going?
Thanks mate, you're a legend!
Oi mate, pass us a beer.
notes: Used by Australians of all ages and backgrounds, 'mate' can be used for anyone from your best friend to someone you've just met.

People.explanation: An old-fashioned Aussie slang term for a woman.
examples: There's a sheila at the door asking for you.
That sheila at the caf was really friendly.
notes: Not commonly used by younger Aussies  sounds a bit dated.

People.explanation: A casual word for a man or guy.
examples: He's a top bloke, always helps his mates out.
Who's that bloke over there with the surfboard?

People.explanation: A fool or an idiot.
examples: You forgot your wallet again, ya drongo!
Don't be a drongo, of course it's closed on Sunday.

People.explanation: A cheeky or playful person who doesn't always follow the rules but is likeable.
examples: He's a bit of a larrikin, always cracking jokes.
The teacher loves him even though he's a total larrikin.
notes: Often used affectionately in Australia.

People.explanation: A slang term for someone with red hair.
examples: That ranga over there plays footy for Wests.
My cousin's a proud ranga.
notes: Can be playful or offensive, depending on how it's used.

People.explanation: An Australian who speaks and behaves in a very stereotypical, exaggerated Aussie way.
examples: He's a real ocker  thick accent, stubby in hand, and all.
The ad used an ocker voice for the voiceover.
notes: Sometimes used negatively, but also with humour.

People.explanation: A crude term for someone who is weak, cowardly or not tough.
examples: He wouldn't go in the water  what a soft cock!
Don't be a soft cock, it's just a bit of rain.
notes: Can be considered vulgar  not for polite company.

People.explanation: Someone who's being stupid or annoying.
examples: He thinks he's cool, but he's just a tool.
Stop acting like a tool and help me.

People.explanation: A big, solid or intimidating person, usually male.
examples: That guy at the gym is a unit!
You see the size of that bouncer? Absolute unit.
notes: Can be said with admiration or just to state the obvious.

People.explanation: An insult meaning someone is acting foolish or silly.
examples: You flamin' galah! You backed into the bin!
Only a flamin' galah would try that.
notes: Galah is a type of pink parrot. The phrase was popularised by the show *Home and Away*.

People.explanation: A joking insult for someone not very bright  like their head is full of cold air.
examples: He's as dumb as an esky lid.
Don't ask him, he's an esky lid when it comes to maths.

People.explanation: A compliment for someone who's done something great or helpful.
examples: You bought the beers? Legend!
Thanks for the lift  you're a bloody legend.
notes: Used often in a light-hearted, matey way.

People.explanation: Someone from the bush (rural Australia).
examples: He's a real bushie, grew up out past Dubbo.
You can tell he's a bushie from the boots and hat.

People.explanation: A rude word for someone who's arrogant, annoying or full of themselves.
examples: Ignore him, he's a total wanker.
That guy on the phone was being such a wanker.
notes: Very common in Australia and the UK  often not taken literally.

People.explanation: A funny or mocking way to describe someone who does something crazy or wild.
examples: He did a backflip off the roof? Sick unit!
You're a sick unit, mate.

People.explanation: Third person reference to a man, often dismissive
examples: Old mate over there thinks he's funny
What's old mate doing now?
Old mate's having a whinge again
notes: Used as a substitute for 'he' when being dismissive

People.explanation: Term of address for women, can be friendly or condescending depending on context
examples: What can I get you, love?
Listen here love, that's not how it works
Thanks love, you're a star
notes: Similar to 'mate' but for women. Context determines if it's friendly or patronizing

People.explanation: A gentle, affectionate insult for someone being foolish
examples: You silly duffer, that's not how you do it!
Don't be such a silly duffer
He's a silly old duffer but we love him
notes: More gentle and affectionate than 'drongo'

People.explanation: Short for relatives, family members
examples: I'm visiting the relos this weekend
How are your relos doing?
The relos are coming for Christmas
notes: Can be singular 'relo' or plural 'relos'

People.explanation: Cashed-up bogan - someone with money but no class
examples: He's a total CUB with his gold chains and flashy car
That's very CUB behavior
She's gone full CUB since winning the lottery
notes: Stands for 'Cashed-Up Bogan' - nouveau riche with poor taste

People.explanation: A bricklayer
examples: My mate's a brickie, he built our back fence
The brickie starts work at 6am
Ask the brickie if he can do our driveway
notes: Australian trades get the -ie suffix treatment

People.explanation: An electrician
examples: Call the sparkie, the power's out
The sparkie said it'll cost 500 bucks
My brother's training to be a sparkie
notes: From 'spark' referring to electricity

People.explanation: A carpenter
examples: The chippie's building our deck
Need a good chippie for the kitchen renovation
My dad was a chippie for 30 years
notes: From 'chips' of wood

People.explanation: Member of a motorcycle gang
examples: The bikies had a big meeting at the pub
He used to be a bikie but cleaned up his act
Don't mess with the bikies
notes: Different from regular motorcyclists - refers specifically to gang members

People.explanation: A farmer, especially one with a large property
examples: The cockie's got 500 head of cattle
Old cockie Jones owns half the district
Life's tough for cockies with the drought
notes: From 'cockatoo' - farmers were seen as squawking about weather and prices

People.explanation: Someone who's arrogant and boastful
examples: He's such a FIGJAM since he got promoted
Don't be a FIGJAM about it
That FIGJAM thinks he's God's gift
notes: Stands for 'F*** I'm Good, Just Ask Me'

People.explanation: A working-class person who struggles but never gives up
examples: She's a real battler, works three jobs
Aussie battlers are the backbone of the country
He's been a battler all his life
notes: Often used with pride - represents the Australian working-class spirit

People.explanation: A soldier, especially from WWI or WWII
examples: My grandfather was a digger in the war
The old diggers march on ANZAC Day
Respect the diggers who fought for our freedom
notes: From soldiers digging trenches in WWI, now used respectfully for all soldiers

People.explanation: An old-fashioned word for friend or mate
examples: How ya going, cobber?
He's a good cobber of mine
Thanks cobber, I owe you one
notes: Quite old-fashioned now, mostly used ironically or by older generations

People.explanation: Nickname for people from Queensland
examples: Those banana benders know how to party
He's a banana bender from up north
Typical banana bender behavior
notes: From Queensland's banana industry - can be used affectionately or dismissively

People.explanation: Nickname for people from Western Australia
examples: Those sandgropers are tough as nails
She's a sandgroper from Perth
Sandgropers know how to handle the heat
notes: From the sandgroper insect found in WA sand

People.explanation: Joking term for people from the next state south
examples: Going to visit the Mexicans in Victoria
He's one of those Mexicans from down south
The Mexicans don't understand real football
notes: Used by NSW people for Victorians, by Queenslanders for NSW people, etc.

People.explanation: An American (pejorative)
examples: The seppos are loud tourists
Typical seppo behavior
He talks like a seppo
notes: From rhyming slang: 'septic tank' = 'yank'. Often mildly insulting

People.explanation: An English person
examples: The poms are whinging about the heat again
He's a pom but he's alright
Typical pom behavior
notes: Can be neutral or mildly insulting. Often expanded to 'pommy bastard'

People.explanation: A New Zealander
examples: The kiwis beat us at rugby again
She's a kiwi from Auckland
Kiwis and Aussies are like siblings
notes: Usually friendly, from New Zealand's national bird

People.explanation: A homeless person or someone who looks disheveled
examples: The park's full of derros drinking goon
He looks like a derro in those old clothes
Don't dress like a derro for the interview
notes: Short for 'derelict' - can be offensive

People.explanation: The designated driver on a night out
examples: Sorry mate, I can't drink - I'm the deso
Who's the deso tonight?
Being the deso sucks but someone has to do it
notes: Short for designated driver

People.explanation: A heroin addict
examples: The smackies hang around the train station
He became a smackie after the accident
Help for smackies is available at the clinic
notes: From 'smack' (heroin) - can be offensive

People.explanation: A crude, uncultured Australian with an exaggerated accent
examples: He's a real ocker - stubby in hand, thick accent
The ad used an ocker voice for the voiceover
Stop acting like an ocker
notes: Stereotypical rough Australian character

People.explanation: A firefighter
examples: The fireys worked all night on the bushfire
My brother's training to be a firey
The fireys deserve a medal for that save
notes: Short for firefighter, used especially in NSW

People.explanation: A cattle rustler or thief
examples: The cattle duffer was caught red-handed
Cattle duffers are still a problem in the outback
He was accused of being a cattle duffer
notes: Historical term for cattle thieves

People.explanation: An American
examples: The yanks are loud tourists
She married a yank and moved to America
Those yanks don't understand cricket
notes: Generally neutral term for Americans

People.explanation: Derogatory term for a New Zealander
examples: Those sheep shaggers beat us at rugby again
Don't call him a sheep shagger, it's offensive
The sheep shaggers make good wine though
notes: Crude stereotype - can be very offensive

People.explanation: A small child
examples: The ankle-biters are running around the yard
Keep an eye on the ankle-biters at the pool
My ankle-biter starts school next year
notes: Affectionate term for young children

People.explanation: An unattractive woman
examples: She's a bit of a bush pig
Don't be mean, calling her a bush pig
He's dating a real bush pig
notes: Very offensive term - avoid using

People.explanation: A woman (when referring to people)
examples: She's a good chook, always helps out
The old chook next door is complaining again
That chook at the shop was really helpful
notes: Can be affectionate or mildly derogatory depending on context

People.explanation: An unfashionable but endearing person
examples: You're such a dag in that outfit
My dad's a total dag but we love him
She's a bit of a dag but really funny
notes: Often used affectionately

People.explanation: A silly or foolish person
examples: Don't be such a galah
You galah, that's not how you do it
He's acting like a complete galah
notes: From the galah bird, known for being noisy and silly

People.explanation: A reckless driver or show-off
examples: That hoon nearly hit us
Stop being a hoon in the car park
The police caught the hoon doing burnouts
notes: Someone who drives dangerously to show off

People.explanation: A young man working on a cattle station
examples: He's working as a jackaroo in Queensland
The jackaroo life is tough but rewarding
My son wants to be a jackaroo
notes: Learning the cattle station trade

People.explanation: A young woman working on a cattle station
examples: She's a jillaroo on a station near Alice Springs
The jillaroo can ride better than most men
Being a jillaroo builds character
notes: Female equivalent of jackaroo

People.explanation: A casual, easygoing person
examples: He's just a knockabout bloke
She's got that knockabout attitude
We need more knockabout people around here
notes: Someone who's relaxed and unpretentious

People.explanation: A mischievous but likeable person
examples: He's a bit of a larrikin but harmless
The larrikin spirit is very Australian
She's got that larrikin sense of humor
notes: Celebrated Australian character type

People.explanation: A foolish person easily taken advantage of
examples: Don't be a mug, he's lying to you
I was a mug to believe that story
Only a mug would pay that much
notes: Someone gullible or naive

People.explanation: A small child
examples: The nippers are playing in the sandpit
Keep the nippers away from the pool
My nipper starts kindie next year
notes: Affectionate term for young children

People.explanation: A stereotypical uncultured Australian
examples: He's a real ocker with the stubby and singlet
Don't act like such an ocker
The ocker accent was thick as treacle
notes: Can be used negatively or with pride

People.explanation: An elderly person or long-time resident
examples: The old timer knows all the local history
Ask the old timer, he's been here forever
That old timer's got some stories
notes: Respectful term for elderly or experienced people

People.explanation: An English person
examples: The pommy tourists are complaining about the heat
He's a pommy but he's alright
Typical pommy behavior
notes: Can be neutral or mildly derogatory

People.explanation: A mischievous person, often used affectionately
examples: You little ratbag, what have you done?
He's a ratbag but we love him
The old ratbag is up to his tricks again
notes: Usually affectionate, especially for children

People.explanation: A tough, unrefined person
examples: He's a rough nut but has a good heart
Don't mess with him, he's a rough nut
She looks like a rough nut but she's sweet
notes: Someone who appears tough or crude

People.explanation: A mischievous person, especially a child
examples: You little scallywag, come here
The scallywag's been in the cookie jar
He's such a scallywag at school
notes: Playful term, often for naughty children

People.explanation: Someone who causes trouble or starts arguments
examples: Don't listen to him, he's just a stirrer
She's a stirrer, always causing drama
The stirrer's at it again
notes: Someone who deliberately creates conflict

People.explanation: A homeless man carrying his possessions in a swag
examples: The old swagman told stories by the fire
Swagmen used to travel the country looking for work
Waltzing Matilda is about a swagman
notes: Historical figure from Australia's past

People.explanation: A wealthy, upper-class person
examples: Look at that toff in his fancy car
The toffs don't understand real work
She married a toff from the eastern suburbs
notes: Often used with mild resentment

People.explanation: Someone who causes problems
examples: He's a known troublemaker around here
Don't be a troublemaker at the party
The troublemaker's been banned from the pub
notes: Someone who deliberately causes issues

People.explanation: An uncouth, rowdy person
examples: The yobbos were making noise all night
Don't act like a yobbo at the restaurant
Those yobbos got kicked out of the club
notes: Similar to 'bogan' but emphasizes rowdy behavior

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, 'thongs' are rubber flip-flops or sandals worn on the feet.
examples: Don't forget to pack your thongs for the beach
I can't come into the restaurant because I'm only wearing thongs
notes: In America and many other countries, 'thongs' refer to underwear or G-strings, which can cause confusion for visitors.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, the 'boot' is the storage compartment at the back of a car.
examples: Can you put the groceries in the boot?
The boot was too small for all our camping gear
notes: In America, this is called the 'trunk'. 'Boot' also means footwear everywhere.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, a 'barbie' is short for barbecue, referring to both the cooking device and the social gathering.
examples: We're having a barbie this weekend if you want to come
Tom's firing up the barbie to cook some snags
notes: In most other countries, 'Barbie' primarily refers to the famous doll.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, a 'rubber' is an eraser used to remove pencil marks.
examples: Can I borrow your rubber? I made a mistake on my drawing
The teacher asked everyone to use a rubber to fix their work
notes: In America, 'rubber' is slang for a condom, which can lead to awkward situations when Australian schoolchildren ask to borrow one.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, to 'root' means to have sex, while in other countries it means to support or cheer for someone or something.
examples: Sarah and Dave were rooting in the back room at the party
An American tourist said they were 'rooting for Australia' in the Olympics and everyone laughed
notes: Be very careful saying you're 'rooting for a team' in Australia!

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, 'tea' can mean dinner or the evening meal, not just the hot beverage.
examples: What's for tea tonight, Mum?
We're having steak for tea
notes: This usage is common in rural areas. It can confuse visitors expecting a cup of tea.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, 'pissed' means drunk, while in America it usually means angry.
examples: I got absolutely pissed at the pub last night
He was too pissed to drive home
notes: 'Pissed off' still means angry in Australia, so context matters.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, an 'entre' is a starter or appetizer served before the main meal.
examples: We had calamari for entre before the steak main course
The restaurant serves three entres and five main options
notes: In America, 'entre' refers to the main course itself, which can cause confusion when dining out.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, a 'banger' usually means a sausage, but elsewhere it can mean a great song or an old car.
examples: Throw a few bangers on the barbie
I love a bacon and banger brekkie
notes: In British slang, 'banger' can also mean an old, beat-up car.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, to 'barrack' means to support or cheer for a sports team. In America, it means to heckle or shout against.
examples: Who do you barrack for in the footy?
I barrack for the Bombers, always have
notes: Another word that means opposite things depending on where you are!

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, 'bathers' means swimwear, like a swimsuit or swimming trunks.
examples: Don't forget your bathers, we're heading to the beach.
She wore new bathers to the pool party.
notes: In other countries, 'bathers' can mean people who are bathing, not the clothing.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, 'muffler' can mean both a scarf and the part of a car that reduces noise.
examples: It's freezing out, grab your muffler!
My car's muffler fell off  it sounds like a tractor now.
notes: This double meaning exists in other countries too, but can still confuse learners.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, 'paddle' can mean both a tool used to row and a small ice cream on a stick (like a 'Paddle Pop').
examples: Let's go for a paddle in the kayak.
Can I get a rainbow paddle from the servo?
notes: 'Paddle Pop' is a brand of ice cream, but Aussies often just call it a 'paddle'.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, a 'ringer' is someone who works on a cattle station. Elsewhere, it means a duplicate or imposter.
examples: He worked as a ringer out near Longreach.
That's not the real trophy  it's a ringer!
notes: In the U.S., 'dead ringer' means an exact copy. Very different meanings.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, a 'station' can be a massive rural property (like a ranch), not just a train station.
examples: She grew up on a cattle station in the outback.
notes: Australians may use 'station' the way Americans use 'ranch'.

Homonyms.explanation: In Australia, to be 'bogged' means your car is stuck, usually in mud or sand.
examples: We got bogged trying to drive on the beach.
Make sure you bring recovery gear in case we get bogged.
notes: Outside of Australia, this meaning is less common. 'Bogged down' can also mean overwhelmed or delayed.

Fighting.explanation: In Australia, a 'blue' is a fight or punch-up, often a spontaneous one.
examples: There was a massive blue out the front of the RSL last night.
He's always getting into blues after a few beers.
notes: Can be used as both a noun ('a blue') and a verb ('he blued with him').

Fighting.explanation: A stoush is an argument or fight, often physical or political.
examples: He got into a stoush with the neighbour over the fence line.
There was a bit of a stoush at the pub but nothing serious.
notes: Used in politics too: 'a political stoush'.

Fighting.explanation: To punch on means to start or get into a fight.
examples: A couple of blokes were punchin' on near the kebab shop.
It was all good until someone spilled a drink and they started punchin' on.
notes: Often used as 'punch on' or 'having a punch on'.

Fighting.explanation: To belt someone is to hit them hard, usually with a punch.
examples: He belted me in the jaw, I didn't see it coming.
If you mouth off again I'll belt ya!

Fighting.explanation: To 'cop one' means to get hit, especially by a punch.
examples: He was mouthing off and copped one right in the nose.
You'll cop one if you keep going like that.
notes: 'Cop it sweet' is a related Aussie phrase meaning 'take it without complaining'.

Fighting.explanation: A king hit is a sudden, hard punch that knocks someone out. Often cowardly and unexpected.
examples: He got king hit outside the club  dropped like a sack of spuds.
The footage showed him king hitting the guy from behind.
notes: Now often called a 'coward punch' in Australian media due to legal awareness.

Fighting.explanation: A hard punch delivered unexpectedly, usually from behind or when the victim isn't ready.
examples: That bloke was jailed for a coward punch that killed a kid in Sydney.
They've launched a campaign to stop coward punches.
notes: Replaces the older term 'king hit' in campaigns to reduce alcohol-related violence.

Fighting.explanation: To give someone stick is to tease, provoke or even physically confront them.
examples: The boys were giving him stick all night about his new haircut.
He gave the ref a bit too much stick and got sent off.
notes: Not always violent, can also mean 'hassle' or 'sledge'.

Fighting.explanation: To go hands means to start throwing punches or fight physically.
examples: They were arguing and then they went hands outside the pub.
He's always ready to go hands, even over nothing.

Fighting.explanation: To lay into someone means to attack or beat them badly, often with multiple punches.
examples: The bouncer laid into the guy after he swung first.
He got laid into by the whole footy team.

Fighting.explanation: To drop someone is to knock them to the ground with a punch.
examples: He dropped him with one punch!
That bloke got dropped like a sack of potatoes.

Fighting.explanation: To 'sort someone out' can mean to fight or threaten to settle something physically.
examples: I'll sort you out if you touch my car again.
They went round to sort him out after the argument.
notes: Can also mean to 'handle something', but in a fighting context it means confrontation.

Fighting.explanation: To swing means to throw a punch.
examples: He swung at me first, so I just defended myself.
The guy was swinging wildly  didn't land much though.

Fighting.explanation: To go toe to toe means to fight face-to-face, usually fairly.
examples: They went toe to toe in the carpark.
It was a fair fight  just two lads going toe to toe.
notes: Used for both physical and sporting matchups.

Sports.explanation: Australian Football League - the premier Australian rules football competition
examples: Are you watching the AFL grand final?
Which AFL team do you barrack for?
notes: AFL is the most popular sport in Melbourne and Adelaide, while NRL dominates in Sydney and Brisbane.

Sports.explanation: Can refer to either AFL (Australian Rules) or rugby league, depending on which state you're in
examples: Let's watch the footy tonight
He's playing footy for the local club
notes: In Victoria and South Australia, 'footy' usually means AFL. In NSW and Queensland, it often means rugby league.

Sports.explanation: A spectacular mark (catch) in AFL, usually taken high above other players
examples: Did you see that specky he took in the third quarter?
That was mark of the year material - what a specky!
notes: Short for 'spectacular mark'. One of the most exciting moments in AFL.

Sports.explanation: An extremely high mark in AFL where a player jumps on another player's back or shoulders
examples: He took a massive hanger over three defenders
That hanger will be on the highlights reel for years
notes: Named because the player appears to 'hang' in the air. Often controversial if deemed dangerous.

Sports.explanation: In AFL, when the ball goes between the goal post and behind post, worth 1 point
examples: He kicked it wide for a behind
That's six goals and four behinds
notes: A goal is worth 6 points, a behind is worth 1 point. Scores are written as goals.behinds (total points).

Sports.explanation: In AFL, a goal kicked after the final siren that can still count if the player was awarded the mark before the siren
examples: He kicked the winning goal after the siren!
The match isn't over until after the siren

Sports.explanation: The Brownlow Medal - AFL's most prestigious individual award for the best and fairest player
examples: He's a chance for the Brownlow this year
The Brownlow count is always exciting
notes: Awarded based on votes from umpires throughout the season.

Sports.explanation: The Melbourne Cricket Ground - Australia's most famous sporting venue
examples: The grand final's always at the 'G
Nothing beats watching footy at the 'G
notes: Capacity of 100,024 makes it the largest cricket stadium in the world.

Sports.explanation: National Rugby League - the premier rugby league competition in Australia
examples: The NRL grand final is huge in Sydney
He plays NRL for the Broncos
notes: Most popular in NSW and Queensland. Different from rugby union.

Sports.explanation: Annual rugby league series between Queensland and New South Wales - Australia's biggest sporting rivalry
examples: Origin night is massive in Australia
Queensland won Origin again this year
notes: Often just called 'Origin'. Players represent the state where they first played rugby league.

Sports.explanation: In rugby league and union, when a player grounds the ball in the opponent's in-goal area, worth 4 points (league) or 5 points (union)
examples: He scored a brilliant try in the corner
That try sealed the victory

Sports.explanation: In rugby, the kick taken after scoring a try to earn extra points
examples: He nailed the conversion from the sideline
That's a tough conversion to kick
notes: Worth 2 points in both league and union.

Sports.explanation: In rugby, a scrum is when players pack together to restart play after a foul
examples: The ref called a scrum after the illegal tackle
They have really big players so their scrum is really strong
notes: More important in rugby union than rugby league.

Sports.explanation: Australia's national rugby union team
examples: The Wallabies are playing the All Blacks
He got selected for the Wallabies
notes: Named after the wallaby, a native Australian animal.

Sports.explanation: Australia's national rugby league team
examples: The Kangaroos won the World Cup
He's been picked for the Kangaroos
notes: Also called the 'Roos'. Different from the AFL team North Melbourne Kangaroos.

Sports.explanation: Cricket series between Australia and England - one of sport's oldest rivalries
examples: Australia retained the Ashes
The Ashes series is always intense
notes: Named after a satirical obituary saying English cricket had 'died' and been 'cremated'.

Sports.explanation: The cap worn by Australian Test cricket players
examples: He earned his baggy green
The baggy green is sacred in Australian cricket
notes: Considered one of the highest honors in Australian sport.

Sports.explanation: In cricket, either the three wooden stumps or when a batsman is dismissed
examples: He took five wickets
The wicket is playing really well today
notes: Can also refer to the pitch condition.

Sports.explanation: In cricket, when a batsman scores 100 runs in a single innings
examples: He scored a brilliant century
That's his third century this season
notes: Often just called a 'ton'. A major milestone for any batsman.

Sports.explanation: In backyard cricket, a rule where hitting the ball over the fence is six runs but you're also out
examples: That's six and out mate!
We're playing six and out rules
notes: Common rule in Australian backyard cricket to keep the ball in play.

Sports.explanation: Verbal intimidation or banter directed at opponents, especially in cricket
examples: The Aussies are famous for their sledging
He copped some serious sledging out there
notes: Australia is considered the home of cricket sledging.

Sports.explanation: Controversial cricket bowling tactic targeting the batsman's body, used by England against Australia in 1932-33
examples: The bodyline series nearly caused a diplomatic incident
That's almost bodyline bowling
notes: Led to changes in cricket laws and strained Australia-England relations.

Sports.explanation: Australia's premier motor racing championship, now called Supercars Championship
examples: The V8 Supercars are racing at Bathurst
He drives in V8 Supercars
notes: Bathurst 1000 is the most famous race.

Sports.explanation: Mount Panorama Circuit in Bathurst, NSW - home of Australia's most famous motor race
examples: Bathurst is the holy grail of Australian motorsport
He won Bathurst three times
notes: The Bathurst 1000 is often called 'The Great Race'.

Sports.explanation: Popular women's sport in Australia, similar to basketball but with different rules
examples: She plays netball for the Diamonds
Netball is huge in Australian schools
notes: Australia's national team is called the Diamonds.

Sports.explanation: Surf lifesaving competition combining swimming, board paddling, ski paddling and beach running
examples: He won the Ironman championship
The Ironman series is on TV
notes: Different from triathlon - this is specifically surf lifesaving.

Rude.explanation: Uniquely in Australia, this extremely offensive word in other countries is often used casually between friends
examples: He's a good cunt, would do anything for ya
Oi cunt, chuck us a beer would ya?
Those cunts over there are causing trouble
notes: The level of offensiveness completely depends on tone and context - can be friendly or extremely hostile
Using with 'sick', 'mad' or 'good' in front makes it a compliment

Rude.explanation: An idiot or fool - a classic Australian insult
examples: What a drongo, he tried to microwave a tin can
Don't be such a drongo, you'll get yourself hurt
notes: Named after a racehorse from the 1920s that never won a race

Rude.explanation: Someone who is extremely stupid or idiotic
examples: What kind of fuckwit parks across two spaces?
That fuckwit nearly caused an accident

Rude.explanation: A fool or idiot, commonly used Australian insult
examples: Don't be a dickhead, give him his phone back
That dickhead cut me off in traffic

Rude.explanation: A derogatory term for someone considered uncultured or unsophisticated
examples: Look at those bogans with their mullets and flannies
He's such a bogan, drinks VB and drives a Holden with a Southern Cross sticker
notes: Similar to 'chav' in the UK or 'redneck' in the US, but with its own distinct Australian flavor

Rude.explanation: A stupid, annoying person or troublemaker
examples: Those gronks are always causing trouble at the pub
Don't be such a gronk, mate

Rude.explanation: Someone who is pretentious, annoying or self-important
examples: Look at him with his fancy car, what a wanker
Don't be such a wanker about it
notes: In Australia, 'wanker' is more about attitude and less about the literal meaning

Rude.explanation: Short for 'derelict' - a disheveled, dirty or homeless person
examples: The park is full of deros drinking goon
Don't dress like a dero for the interview

Rude.explanation: Used to emphasize that something is absolutely true or someone is completely stupid
examples: He's deadset the dumbest person I've ever met
She's deadset insane if she thinks that'll work

Rude.explanation: An iconic Australian insult meaning a foolish or stupid person
examples: You flamin' galah, that's not how you do it!
Stop being such a flamin' galah
notes: Made famous by Alf Stewart in Home and Away

Rude.explanation: A versatile Australian swear word that can express frustration, surprise, or describe a troublesome person
examples: Bugger! I forgot my wallet
The little bugger stole my parking spot
Well, I'll be buggered!

Rude.explanation: A person who behaves badly or causes trouble, but often in a somewhat affectionate way
examples: The old ratbag always tells the same stories
You're a bit of a ratbag, aren't ya?

Rude.explanation: Can be an insult or term of endearment depending on context
examples: He's a lucky bastard, won the lottery twice
You clever bastard, that's brilliant!
That bastard stole my wallet
notes: Often preceded by adjectives like 'poor', 'lucky', 'clever', 'silly' or 'old' which make it friendlier

Rude.explanation: A goofy, unfashionable person - can be affectionate
examples: Look at you in that outfit, you're such a dag
My dad's a total dag, always telling bad jokes
notes: Originally referred to dried feces hanging from sheep wool

Rude.explanation: Someone who is very promiscuous or constantly looking for sexual partners
examples: He's a bit of a root rat, sleeps with anyone
She's become such a root rat since the divorce
notes: 'Root' in Australia means to have sex, so be careful asking about 'rooting for a team'

Rude.explanation: A dumb, useless person. Pure insult, no affection.
examples: That dropkick couldn't even plug in a toaster.
You're such a bloody dropkick, mate.
notes: Originally a rugby term, now means a complete idiot.

Rude.explanation: A very offensive term for someone who's a terrible person  the opposite of a 'good cunt'.
examples: Don't talk to him, he's a proper shitcunt.
He nicked my wallet and ran off. Shitcunt move.
notes: Very vulgar. Can be used seriously or in banter depending on the crowd.

Rude.explanation: Someone who's wild, unpredictable, or a bit crazy  usually meant as praise.
examples: Did you see that backflip? You're a mad cunt!
He stole a shopping trolley and rode it down the hill  mad cunt.
notes: Only Aussies can make 'mad' and 'cunt' together sound affectionate.

Rude.explanation: A term of high praise for someone who is cool, brave or legendary.
examples: You got us backstage? Sick cunt!
That sick cunt just pulled a burnout in front of the cops.
notes: One of the most Aussie ways to say someone is awesome  offensive elsewhere.

Rude.explanation: An idiot, tool or tryhard  often a poser or someone full of themselves.
examples: He talks like he's on Love Island. Total flog.
Only a flog would wear sunnies indoors at night.
notes: Also used as a verb: 'He flogged me in FIFA last night' (meaning 'beat badly').

Rude.explanation: Short for 'poverty'  used to describe something or someone cheap, poor or low quality.
examples: That povo lunch was just two dry sandwiches.
He bought a povo brand phone from Kmart.
notes: Can be classist if used about people. Also used jokingly.

Rude.explanation: A wanker, fool or someone behaving like a dick.
examples: That tosser cut in line at the servo.
He's acting like a real tosser tonight.
notes: More common in British English but still used in Australia.

Rude.explanation: A crude insult implying someone is thinking with their genitals or just generally being dumb.
examples: Nice one, dickbrain  now the car won't start.
You're a dickbrain if you believe that.

Rude.explanation: A classic insult meaning idiot or fool  same vibe as dickhead but milder.
examples: You absolute knob, that was my beer!
He's being a knob about the whole thing.

Rude.explanation: An idiot or person acting like a fool. A very Aussie way to call someone dumb or annoying.
examples: Don't be a tool, it's not that hard.
He's a good bloke but a total tool when he's drunk.
notes: Often affectionate among mates.

Rude.explanation: A coward, someone who's soft or easily scared.
examples: Don't be a wuss, it's just a spider.
He wouldn't get in the water  bloody wuss.

Rude.explanation: A crude and often sexist term for a woman who sleeps around.
examples: She's such a slapper, she hooked up with three guys last night.
That slapper rocked up in a crop top in winter.
notes: Not as common anymore, and definitely offensive  especially to women.

Rude.explanation: A harsh insult for a woman  worse than 'bitch', but not as strong as 'cunt'.
examples: She stole my man, what a mole.
You're being a right bloody mole today.

Rude.explanation: Someone who drinks way too much or is constantly getting drunk.
examples: That pisshead was passed out on the lawn again.
He's a mad pisshead but he's always up for a laugh.

Rude.explanation: Someone who avoids work or responsibility. Can also be used for lazy people in general.
examples: That bludger hasn't moved off the couch all day.
Stop being a bludger and mow the bloody lawn.
notes: Can be light-hearted or scathing, depending on delivery.

Rude.explanation: Someone who's full of themselves or acts stupidly
examples: Don't be such a pelican

Rude.explanation: An expression of shock, surprise or disbelief
examples: Fuck me dead, look at the size of that spider!
You won the lottery? Fuck me dead!
Fuck me dead, that was expensive
notes: Despite the wording, it's just an exclamation, not literal

Rude.explanation: A brawl or fist fight
examples: There was a biff outside the pub
He's always getting into biffs
The biff started over nothing
notes: Also spelled 'biffo'

Rude.explanation: An idiot or foolish person
examples: Don't be such a nong
He's a complete nong
Only a nong would try that
notes: Sometimes 'ning-nong' for emphasis

Rude.explanation: Broken, not working properly, or extremely drunk
examples: My car is ratshit, won't start
He was ratshit drunk last night
This phone is ratshit

Rude.explanation: Extremely angry
examples: Dad was ropeable when he saw the car
She's ropeable about the exam results

notes: So angry you need to be tied up with rope

Rude.explanation: Very rough, bumpy, or of poor quality
examples: This road is rough as guts
He's rough as guts but good-hearted
The weather was rough as guts
